author: Marc Berman
title: Charles Oakley and Knicks talk truce | New York Post
text:
Knicks owner James Dolan and Charles Oakley’s camp are “trying to find a compromise’’ to end the nasty feud that led to the fan favorite’s ejection and arrest last Wednesday and subsequent ban from Madison Square Garden, according to a source familiar with the situation.
The Garden would not comment.
It is unclear whether Dolan and Oakley have talked directly, but Oakley’s camp has made contact with the Knicks one day after the owner ended his feud with Latrell Sprewell in a public display at the Garden .
Oakley, a power forward for the revered Knicks teams of the 1990s, was banned last Friday following the incident in which he was arrested and charged with three counts of misdemeanor assault and one count of misdemeanor trespassing.
Dolan, the Knicks owner, said Oakley was ejected for being verbally abusive to security, which Oakley denied. Dolan said he suspects Oakley may have a drinking problem, which the former Knick also denied.
The Knicks have received blow-back from the ban, including demands from Brooklyn borough president Eric Adams and Rev. Al Sharpton to drop the ban and charges against Oakley. Sharpton said in a statement on Monday his National Action Network will organize a group to picket outside of the Garden if the situation isn’t reolved.
At a press conference on Monday afternoon, Adams said a scheduled meeting with Dolan was postponed after he was told “new developments” arose.
